title: 112_hr1259
content:
The "Death Tax Repeal Permanency Act of 2011" is cited as the short title. It repeals estate and generation-skipping transfer taxes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Death Tax Repeal Permanency Act of 2011 terminates the application of estate taxes to decedents dying after its enactment. It also modifies the application of certain distributions from qualified domestic trusts for decedents before the Act's enactment. Additionally, it repeals the generation-skipping transfer tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Death Tax Repeal Permanency Act of 2011 terminates the application of estate taxes to decedents dying after its enactment. It also repeals the generation-skipping transfer tax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Death Tax Repeal Permanency Act of 2011 terminates estate taxes for decedents dying after its enactment, excluding certain provisions related to carryover basis at death. The Death Tax Repeal Permanency Act of 2011 eliminates estate taxes for decedents dying after its enactment, excluding certain provisions related to carryover basis at death. Section 304 of the Tax Relief, Unemployment Insurance Reauthorization, and Job Creation Act of 2010 is repealed, with the amendments applying to estates of decedents dying and generation-skipping transfers after the enactment of this Act. MODIFICATIONS OF GIFT TAX: The computation of gift tax under section 2502 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to determine the tax for each calendar year based on the aggregate sum of taxable gifts. The tentative tax rates for different income brackets are as follows:
- Not over $10,000: 18% of the amount
- Over $10,000 but not over $20,000: $1,800 plus 20% of the excess
- Over $20,000 but not over $40,000: $3,800 plus 22% of the excess
- Over $40,000 but not over $60,000: $8,200 plus 24% of the excess
- Over $60,000 but not over $80,000: $13,000 plus 26% of the excess
- Over $80,000 but not over $100,000: $18,200 plus 28% of the excess
- Over $100,000 but not over $150,000: $23,800 plus 30% of the excess For incomes over $100,000 but not over $150,000, the tax rate is $23,800 plus 30% of the excess. For incomes over $150,000 but not over $250,000, the tax rate is $38,800 plus 32% of the excess. For incomes over $250,000 but not over $500,000, the tax rate is $70,800 plus 34% of the excess. For incomes over $500,000, the tax rate is $155,800 plus 35% of the excess. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include changes to the treatment of transfers in trust as taxable gifts, unless the trust is wholly owned by the donor or donor's spouse. Additionally, the lifetime gift exemption amount is adjusted to $5,000,000. The tax is to be computed at $5,000,000, with amendments made to section 2505 of the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments to section 2505 of the Internal Revenue Code apply to gifts made on or after the enactment of this Act. A transition rule treats the calendar year of enactment as two separate calendar years for tax purposes.
